vehicles.name: Longship (Drekar)
vehicles.desc: The quintessential Viking warship. Long, narrow, shallow-drafted, and terrifyingly fast for its era. Built to cross the North Atlantic and then sail up rivers to strike where no one expects. The dragon prow isn't decoration — it's a statement of intent.
vehicles.notes: The longship's defining advantage is Shallow Draft. She goes where deeper vessels cannot follow — up rivers, into estuaries, onto beaches. Build encounters around this mobility. The Vikings don't fight fair; they appear where they shouldn't be, strike hard, and vanish before the local lord can muster a response.

vehicles.name: Snekkja
vehicles.desc: Smaller and faster than the drekar, the snekkja is a raiding vessel pure and simple. Twenty oars, a single mast, and enough room for thirty warriors and whatever they steal. She's the vessel that appears at dawn in your harbour while you're still asleep.
vehicles.notes: The snekkja is your ambush predator. Use two or three together for a wolf-pack raid. Individually they're fragile, but their speed means the players have to catch them before they scatter — and each one runs in a different direction.

vehicles.name: Skeid
vehicles.desc: The great longship. Thirty oars a side, a crew of over a hundred, and the prestige vessel of a jarl or king. She's too valuable to risk on casual raids — the skeid sails when the entire war-fleet sails, and her presence means someone is serious about conquest rather than plunder.
vehicles.notes: The skeid signals escalation. When one appears, the stakes have risen from 'raiders hit a village' to 'an invasion fleet has arrived.' Use her as the flagship of an NPC war-leader the players need to stop, board, or negotiate with. Her crew is enormous and well-armed.

vehicles.name: Knarr
vehicles.desc: Wide-beamed, deep-hulled, and slow. The knarr is a cargo vessel — the ship that carried families, livestock, tools, and supplies across the Atlantic to Iceland, Greenland, and Vinland. She's not glamorous, but without her the Viking expansion never happens.
vehicles.notes: The knarr is your escort mission. She carries something irreplaceable — settlers, tribute, sacred relics, or the jarl's family — and she's slow enough that every enemy vessel on the sea can catch her. The players protect her, and every encounter is a desperate rearguard action.

vehicles.name: Byzantine Chelandion
vehicles.desc: The warship of the Eastern Roman Empire, equipped with the most devastating naval weapon of the medieval world: Greek fire. A pressurised siphon mounted at the bow sprays liquid flame across the water's surface. It burns on contact with water. It cannot be extinguished.
vehicles.notes: Greek fire is terrifying and should be treated as such. The flame projector uses the Cone Template and ignores Waterborne protection. Wooden longships burn beautifully. Use the chelandion as the reason the Vikings don't just sail into Constantinople — they tried once, and the survivors never forgot.

vehicles.name: Arab Dhow
vehicles.desc: A lateen-rigged vessel of the Indian Ocean trade routes, fast and weatherly, capable of sailing closer to the wind than any square-rigged ship of the same era. The dhow is a merchant vessel first, but in these waters every merchant is also a potential pirate, and vice versa.
vehicles.notes: The dhow represents the wider world beyond the Viking theatre. Use her to remind the players that the Norse weren't the only seafarers of the age. An encounter with a dhow means exotic cargo, unfamiliar fighting techniques, and trade routes that lead to adventures far from Scandinavia.

vehicles.name: Norman Ship
vehicles.desc: The vessel that carried William's army across the Channel. Essentially a longship with higher sides and a broader beam, modified to carry horses, armoured knights, and siege equipment. She's a troop transport that looks like a warship.
vehicles.notes: The Norman ship is a landing craft. She delivers a cavalry charge onto a beach, which is one of the most dramatic tactical images in medieval warfare. Use her for invasion scenarios where the players must either stop the landing or participate in it. The horses panicking in the hold during rough weather is a complication that writes itself.

vehicles.name: Fire Raft
vehicles.desc: Logs lashed together, soaked in pitch, set alight, and pushed toward the enemy anchorage on the current. It's not sophisticated. It doesn't need to be. A wall of fire drifting toward your moored ships at night will break the nerve of any fleet.
vehicles.notes: The fire raft is the medieval fire ship — cheaper, cruder, and surprisingly effective. Use it as a desperate defensive measure when the players' settlement is attacked by a superior fleet. Someone has to build the rafts, time the tide, and light them without being spotted.

vehicles.name: Cog
vehicles.desc: The merchant vessel of the Hanseatic League. Tubby, high-sided, and fitted with fighting castles fore and aft. She carries trade goods along the North Sea routes that made the League rich. Her high sides make her surprisingly defensible against longship boarders.
vehicles.notes: The cog is your trading vessel. The players either own one, protect one, or rob one. Her high sides give defenders a bonus against boarders, which means a cog with a determined crew is much harder to take than it looks. Merchants in this era aren't helpless — they're armed and experienced.

vehicles.name: Currach
vehicles.desc: A small boat of wicker frame covered in animal hide, sealed with tallow. The Irish monks sailed these across the North Atlantic centuries before the Vikings. She's barely a vessel by warship standards, but she's light enough for two men to carry overland between rivers.
vehicles.notes: The currach is your stealth insertion vehicle. She's invisible against a dark coastline, draws almost no water, and can be portaged overland. Use her for infiltration, scouting, or escape — the players abandon their longship to pursue someone up a river too shallow for the drekar, and the only vessel that fits is this ridiculous little hide boat.
